title: 113_hr2574
content: The "Keep Student Loans Affordable Act of 2013" extends the interest rate deadline to July 1, 2014. It also includes modifications to required distribution rules for pension plans. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include required distributions for pension plans when an employee dies before their interest is fully distributed. The distribution of an employee's interest must be completed within 5 years after their death, with an exception for eligible designated beneficiaries. The distribution of an employee's interest after death must be completed within 5 years, except for eligible designated beneficiaries who can receive distributions over their lifetime starting within 1 year. The distribution of an employee's interest after death must be completed within 5 years, except for eligible designated beneficiaries who can receive distributions over their lifetime starting within 1 year. If distributions begin within 1 year after the employee's death, the portion referred to in subclause (I) is treated as distributed on that date. The distribution of an employee's interest after death must be completed within 5 years, except for eligible designated beneficiaries. If the surviving spouse is the beneficiary, distributions must begin no earlier than when the employee would have turned 70. If an eligible designated beneficiary dies before distributions begin, the rules will be applied as if the surviving spouse were the employee. If an eligible designated beneficiary dies before distribution, the remaining portion must be distributed within 5 years after the beneficiary's death. The definition of an eligible designated beneficiary is amended in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The definition of an eligible designated beneficiary is amended in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include any individual designated as a beneficiary by the employee. The term 'eligible designated beneficiary' refers to the surviving spouse, minor child, or disabled individual designated as a beneficiary by the employee in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The curr_chunk discusses individuals who are considered eligible beneficiaries under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including those who have reached majority, are disabled, or are chronically ill. The curr_chunk discusses eligibility criteria for individuals under the Internal Revenue Code, including those with indefinite disabilities or who are not more than 10 years younger than the employee. The curr_chunk explains that an individual described in clause (ii)(II) will cease to be an eligible designated beneficiary when they reach majority, and the requirement of subparagraph (B)(i) will not be met with respect to any remaining portion of an employee's interest payable to the individual. An individual described in clause (ii)(II) will cease to be an eligible designated beneficiary when they reach majority, and the requirement of subparagraph (B)(i) will not be met with respect to any remaining portion of an employee's interest payable to the individual unless such portion is distributed within 5 years. Section 401(a)(9)(C) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include provisions for employees becoming 5-percent owners after age 70\1/2\. The amendments made by this section shall apply to distributions for a plan year ending after the employee attains age 70\1/2\ and becomes a 5-percent owner. The amendments made by this section apply to distributions for employees who die after December 31, 2013, and to employees becoming a 5-percent owner with respect to plan years ending in calendar years before, on, or after the date of enactment of this Act. Employees who become 5-percent owners before 2013 and have not retired by 2014 will be treated as 5-percent owners for the year 2013 for tax purposes. Employees who become 5-percent owners before 2013 and have not retired by 2014 will be treated as such for tax purposes. The amendments made by this section in 2013 apply to designated beneficiaries of employees who die before January 1, 2014, and the designated beneficiary will be treated as an eligible designated beneficiary for tax purposes. An eligible designated beneficiary under section 401(a)(9)(B)(iv) of the Code is exempt from the amendments made by this section. The amendments do not apply to existing qualified annuity contracts in effect before the enactment of this Act. A qualified annuity contract refers to an annuity that is a commercial annuity or payable by a defined benefit plan, with substantially equal periodic payments over the lives of the employee and a designated beneficiary. A qualified annuity contract provides periodic payments over the lives of the employee and a designated beneficiary, following specific regulations outlined in section 401(a)(9)(A)(ii) of the Code. The qualified annuity contract must meet the requirements of section 401(a)(9) of the Code, with annuity payments starting before January 1, 2014, and an irrevocable election made regarding the payment method and amount. The qualified annuity contract must meet the requirements of section 401(a)(9) of the Code, with annuity payments starting before January 1, 2014, and an irrevocable election made regarding the payment method and amount. Annuity payments can be made to the employee or designated beneficiaries based on the employee's election before the enactment of this Act.
